commentBody: Great debut!

A fun romp, over too quickly! I was able to guess about two-thirds of the long answers from only 2 or 3 letters. The others (CARE TO ELABORATE?) only a little more slowly. Still, it was a nice debut and I look forward to more from Scott.

Caitlin calls this one "spectacular but solvable." I agree.
Very clean, and an impressive debut.
Great job, Scott!

IMO this was a great Friday puzzle.
And yes, I know what day it is.
One of my favorite Saturdays in a while. Nice misdirect with the two Yankees.

Jim Horne notes on xwordinfo.com that this is the first triple triple (three stacks of three spanners each) in ten years.

Triple stacks can be daunting upon first glance, but if the long answers come easily, the puzzle can open up very quickly.  

All three in the top group opened up really fast after some of the gimme crosses were in place:  NEIN, ATS, etc.

In the second stack, OSCAR NOMINATION seemed like a good guess, and some gimmes on the crosses not only confirmed it, but opened it up for the other two spanners.

In the last group, HOTEL CALIFORNIA was a gimme off just a few crosses, ITALIAN AMERICAN was easy at that point to fill in, too, and by the time I got to TESTED THE WATERS, I already had at least half the letters already in place.

I moved through this puzzle surprised that for a Saturday, it offered little resistance.  

I'm going to guess that even those who struggle with Saturday puzzles are going to struggle less than usual with this one.

A minor-and-admittedly-incorrect snit-fit; while the album "HOTEL CALIFORNIA" was technically released in 1976, it was in December, and didn't hit number one until 1977, and didn't win the Grammy until 1978 so I was busy trying to fit in something from Captain and Tenille into 53A. Sigh.

Still, I'm very impressed with the triple-triple stack!
A Mandrill is not a primate. It is a monkey. Just sayin'.

Great fun. I got all of the long ones easily, and had near my best time for a Saturday.

Trivia:  Port MAHON is the origin of Mayonnaise. It also features prominently in the ‚ÄúMaster and Commander‚Äù series of 20 novels by Patrick O‚ÄôBrian.

L

Just as smooth as Hotel California -- which is probably not the song people want on the radio right now in southern Cali (it's really horrifyingly unimaginable...those videos, those flames, those drone's eye views of the Palisades and Altadena, there really are no words to give understanding or meaning to the experience of those who are enduring it --) and I love the grid design, those two horizontal...pulse rates? Seismographs? Post-modern musical score? Results of a polygraph test?

Sneaky touch, having "McMahon" almost spelled out in the first two downs:
A M
C A
C H
R O
A N

And the MUM/MIME intersection. Silent applause for that one!

Relax, said the nightman, we are programmed to receive:
you can check out any time, but you can never leave...

As glad as I always am to see 15-letter answers in a puzzle, and as much as I respect the construction of this one, it was much, much too easy for a Saturday, bordering on Wednesday-level toughness.  Disappointing.

5/10

I finished this pretty quickly and rather aggressively disliked it the entire time.  It was all the obscure-to-me proper naming, which normally doesn't bother me all that much. But here it seemed particularly gratuitous, as if it were purposely hitting me over the head every other clue.

I guess the puzzle was fairly constructed in the end - I solved it without much stress or drama.  But I can't say I enjoyed it.  Pretty looking grid though!

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

I'll crack one yolk about omelettes for free, but the rest will cost eggstra.

(Besides, my brain is fried.)
Regarding 27A.  Have you not heard?  It was my understanding that everyone had heard.

This puzzle was a triple treat for sure.  Three grid spanning stacks with a funky looking grid that virtually isolated the three sections made it seem almost like three separate puzzles.  I got the middle section first by knowing about Katherine Hepburn‚Äôs OSCARNOMINATIONS and about SPANISHOMELETTEs.  I got the bottom section almost as easily by knowing HOTELCALIFORNIA, which gave me enough letters to get enough downs to see the other spanners (although I did try to find a way to work Yankees into the Berra DiMaggio clue before ITALIANAMERICANS came to me).  But I whiffed badly on the top section.  All I could think of for 1A was ablewasiereisawelba, which made no sense for the downs and caused me no end of grief.  For some reason the equally well known AMANAPLANACANALpanama would not come to me, until I started over, got NARC and guessed that ACCRA was the African art center. Lovely puzzle.

I‚Äôm a big  admirer of Katherine Hepburn, but perhaps her biggest fan was my first wife.  Like Hepburn, my wife was a Bryn Mawrter, and she got to meet her idol once at a college function. In the course of the evening, Hepburn handed my wife an empty, clear plastic cup that had contained the beverage she was drinking.  Rather than disposing of the cup, as had been expected, she kept the cup and it stayed with us through several moves, as if it were a holy grail, until it finally cracked and fell apart. Now that‚Äôs fandom.

Saturday PB for me at 16 minutes! And that‚Äôs after a full two minutes of not realizing I‚Äôd mindlessly typed in citizen cANE. I imagine if one didn‚Äôt get the extremely long across answers this may have been torture, but getting a few of them made this extremely quick relative to most Saturdays.
Wow, without 31 across - easy for a movie buff - I‚Äôm not sure I would have found a way in! Respectable-for-me 1:13:37 with breaks to assist my husband who brought home a new hip today!
The intersection of CAN and CANT delights me to no end.

Agree this was on the easier side, since once you get one row in a stack the rest fall pretty quickly. And the top row was a gimme for me. But c‚Äômon folks it‚Äôs still enjoyable, and incredibly smooth fill for nine fifteen letter spanners. And in a debut? This is a tour de force and absolutely a worthy Saturday
Absolutely loved this grid! Looked intimidating at first but fell into place fairly quickly
I enjoyed solving this. Nice work out. What a feat of construction! Congrats constructor - nice one.

Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Mr. McMahon!

The three triple stacks made the grid seem daunting at first, but once I had a few answers in the grid, the rest came quickly.

Thanks!
This was a good one. I enjoyed having 9 phrases that went all the way across. I couldn't quite remember Kate Winslet's last name, thinking it was "Winsett" at first .

Great debut! I got stuck on 58A because I was 100% sure the answer was Yankee related.  I didn‚Äôt even know Yogi Berra was ITALIANAMERICAN.

Fun seeing LEO DiCaprio and Kate WINSLET together again.  

Does anyone else go üò¨ seeing LBJ and BARE together? He was ‚Ä¶ something else.

OSCARNOMINATION and SATELLITEDISH came quickly, thankfully, to help with crosses. Loved HOTELCALIFORNIA! I saw Don Henley in concert in the early ‚Äò90s.  Magical evening!

Boa noite üò¥

Outstanding Saturday


I loved the three levels of long crosses.  I worked my way down. Top two thirds were done very quickly for me for a Saturday. 

That last level. Yikes. Like 30 minutes alone. But once I gave up on par as a golfers concern, for LIE. The bottom third fell in lies than a minute. The showed respect clue that needed an entry that started with a K confounded me to no end. 

I can‚Äôt imagine how hard it was to put this kind of grid together.  I really appreciated solving it. 

Thank you Scott McMahon
Fantastic looking grid, fun fill I jived with at 15:34!!
This was my favorite Wednesday in a while! Oh wait...
Super smooth at 11 minutes, my best Saturday yet. Thanks for the PB. Always fun when the full grid length is used.

Nice puzzle. Thanks. 

What do the US army and the drug industry have in common? 

They use the metric system.

Several folks said this felt like a Wednesday puzzle as far as difficulty goes.  I checked my stats and my solve time was very nearly my Wednesday average time‚Ä¶. A minute and a half off my Saturday personal best though‚Ä¶. So yeah, easy.  The triple stacks were fun but yielded with just a few crosses‚Ä¶. Was surprised it was all over so soon‚Ä¶
That was a really spectacular construction. Well done on your debut, Mr McMahon!
Amazingly fun and well-constructed puzzle, but over too quickly! Faster than my previous Thu/Fri/Sat personal bests.

This went very fast but maybe I‚Äôm just tired after a long week, it didn‚Äôt much tickle my fancy.

I didn‚Äôt think the (impressive) spanners made up for the plethora of three- and four- letter words and the trivia.

(Of course, had I done this tomorrow morning with a fresh cup of coffee I probably would have been delighted to learn all the new things revealed here!)

Spanners crossed by multiple trivia entries: my least favorite grid design. I needed multiple lookups and reveals, so I did not enjoy this one at all.

Also, I don't get 'Golfer's concern': LIE. Could somebody please explain?

I didn't understand CANT as 'lingo,' either, but it was easy to look up.
Full spans could've been clued harder, fun though!
Hotel California best record Grammy was 1978 not 1976. Typo?

Strands Thread.  No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #321
‚ÄúO ___! My ___!‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ
Berra and DiMaggio (Mickey Mantle too)were both THREE TIME MVPS, though that doesn‚Äôt quite fit.

The construction was excellent but the cluing was way too simple - I finished in 4:09, which is a time I often miss even on Mondays and Tuesdays. Saturdays for me should take at least 10 minutes, and there should be a lot of little aha moments. Obviously some of this is luck but it's still a bit underwhelming.

CAN and CANT
MIMEs keep MUM
A 'famous' BRIT is Rita ORA
LEO and Kate WINSLET
OSCARNOMINATIONS for LEO, WINSLET, Citizen KANE and GORILLAs in the Mist
LEO could be the name of a big KAT
CATE is another spelling of Kate (WINSLET) or even KAT
If you're SANE, you're TUNEDIN

And Scott McMahon having MAHON as an answer. Priceless.


I might be seeing what I wanna see, but I'm glad I'm seeing it
- Sebastian in London, 2025

Wow. The skill to create this just astounds me. Triple triple stack spanners?!?! ü§Ø Color me impressed with this debut. I solved the middle stack first, the bottom stack next once I let go of par for LIE, but I really struggled with the top stack. I knew NEIN, ATS, and ARIAL were correct, so it couldn‚Äôt be Elba‚Ä¶ I wasn‚Äôt familiar with the palindrome in this case, so I had to use the crosses. Ended up 8 minutes over my average, so definitely not the same easy solve experience others had. Still enjoyed it. Thank you, Scott.
The clue 15d-"Some do-overs"-I got the answer but i still do not understand what it means. Can someone "care to elaborate"?

I feel very fortunate to have completed this puzzle in half of my average time because when I first looked at it and saw the nine spanners, it was a little bit daunting. 

This was almost like working three separate puzzles. I got the middle completely done with only two answers outside the middle then I got the bottom completely done then I got the top.
Why does ‚Äú2‚Äôs‚Äù have an apostrophe? Editor missed that one‚Ä¶ üßê
Can‚Äôt believe that they got the wrong year for the Grammy record. It‚Äôs 1978.
I won't be KOI, I'll just come right out and say, great debut!  Initially intimidated, when I got to the second stack I said, LEMME at it!  Well done and thanks.
Impressive construction, fun to solve. Great debut!
Unenjoyable obscure. full of trivia. The palindrome clue makes zero sense.

I had to look up quite a few. I remembered some, like ETAS and CAN from before, but films, rappers and media stars are not my strong point at all. I couldn't get LEMME because of the first M!
I don't understand ATS or the 5D clue - help please.

The upper 4 rows probably took more than half of my total time.  I wasn't familiar with the palindrome, and I was thinking along the lines of some type of food poisoning for 17 A.  A couple of early issues, like dOg for COP and LEtME for LEMME, didn't help either.  I'm glad because it let me spend a little extra time working that out.

I was speechless when the answer to [It‚Äôs the word] hit me.





Et tu, emu.

i‚Äôm not understanding this one:


41A - informal hookups (IVS) 


??? what am i missing???

Is referring to airbags as "ABs" an American thing that I'm unaware of?

or is it from Crosswordia.

Well, I liked it! I'll admit the long answers scared me a bit, but I got the palindrome right out of the gate and then the Hepburn clue. Finished a little under average and in less time than it took me to get to the airport this morning (and my time would have been better if my driver hadn't been so interesting to talk to). Thanks!

An unusually enjoyable theme-less puzzle. One thing I had noted recently was that it seemed like there were relatively  few grid-spanning entries in recent puzzles and... here we have three triple stacks of 15's. Wow. Of course had to cheat a bit on some down answers but then just lots of nice 'aha' moments when the long across answers finally dawned on me. 

And... seeing Jimmy Carter mentioned was just one more nice addition.

Might do some answer history searches later. Maybe. 

...
Fun puzzle. I especially liked "kilo finder." I was totally on the wrong track for that one.

Greetings and kudos from an impressed solver, down US-12! Just in case anyone hasn't watched the last *two* times it's been shared on wordplay: https://youtube.com/watch?v=BXbW42uTKYo "There's life after default, dahling." "When I look at you, A., I see a chubby, user-friendly me." I cry Natick at the crossing of the writer/philosopher and the rapper--after all, it could be any number of two letters!
Noticed someone completed today's puzzle in just over four minutes. Even if I knew all the answers beforehand, I'm not sure I could plug them in that fast.

Even after all my years of solving, there‚Äôs still something magical to me when I‚Äôm looking at a long answer with a paucity of crosses, and with a huge KAPOW the answer hits me.  That flash of seeing -- it‚Äôs one of my favorite Crosslandia moments.

Today that happened a good number of times, and when a solve is stuffed with that much giddiness, well, I spontaneously feel buoyant and grateful, and I don‚Äôt care what the day is, the puzzle did its job. 

CARE TO ELABORATE, OSCAR NOMINATION, SPANISH OMELETTE, ITALIAN AMERICAN, and TESTED THE WATERS are lovely spanners, bringing beauty to the box.  

Plus, more loveliness from a couple of clues that misdirected me in [Chest beating sort] and [Cry after a close shave], not to mention a pair of sweet crosses (mentioned by other posters here) in MUM / MIME, and CAN / CANT.

It‚Äôs so very hard to create a triple stack whose crossing answers have hardly a whiff of junk, much less *three* triple stacks, and, IMO, that‚Äôs just what Scott did ‚Äì in his debut puzzle.  Wow!

You rule today, Scott.  Congratulations and enjoy your Debut Day.  Thank you for a splendid outing, and please, don‚Äôt be a stranger!

Strangely, A MAN A PLAN A HOSTILE TAKEOVER didn't fit.

(Going out on a flag-pole here.)
Usually, I move on quickly to Spelling Bee after completing the Crossword, but not today.  I'm lingering in admiration.  What a joy to solve!
Anyone think 7D ‚ÄúI can handle this!‚Äù is a little too formal for LEMME? ‚ÄúYeah I can do it!‚Äù might have been better. I mention it because the T in my original LETME threw me for a while.

A couple things (like LEMME, and the clue [Informal preposition] ) got me off to a grouchy start on this one for some reason, and that lasted until the end, which didn‚Äôt take very long. But on review, the more I look and NOTE, the more I appreciate and even like this puzzle. 

Gnarly like a burl - so put that in your pipe and smoke it, Scott McMahon :)
What a fun solve! The palindrome cut solving time in half, but I couldn't stop smiling after turning down a Hamburger!
Speedy Saturday! The long answers were Tuesday easy and some of the shorts were Saturday obscura....unusual fun for today...thanks Scott!
Initially daunting, but very fair. I was certain it was SELAH (Arabic for prayer), and that combined with  an overlooked misspelling (‚ÄúITILIANAMERICAN‚Äù) ended my little streak. Sad.

Implausibly brisk solve for me. Feels like my fastest Saturday, though I don't pay attention to the timer. I seemed to be on the right wavelength for enough of the downs, and then to see the long crosses fairly early.
Last to fall was BRIT. I had no idea what _RIT was [Person partial to humour?],  because of course I didn't notice the BrE spelling as unusual until after I solved with the cross.
How is a Brit a person partial to humour? Because of the U? Argh!

Same comments as yesterday, lightly altered:

A lovely candidate for a "themeless Wednesday" puzzle. Seemed awfully gentle for a Saturday; solved it in a third my Saturday average (and missed a PB by 10 seconds). This was likely due to the many entries that were long phrases, which I  find easy to discern and that provide me with lots of letters. Quite a few proper nouns in the grid, but, atypically, these did not slow me down. 

Congrats on the debut!

That. Was. Brilliant. One of the most fiendish but enjoyable puzzles I‚Äôve ever done.
The first glance at all that white space was terrifying. First pass was no better. No clue as to the palindrome, or indeed to any of the long spans. Filled in a few of the little ones; TIL, KOI, MUM but still so much open grid.
Very, very slowly I filled in a few gaps. ITALIAN AMERICAN was my eventual way in. I was so pleased with myself for getting it. Sports! US sportsmen! 
It felt truly thrilling as I managed to see each long span (I know, I should get out more). I needed Caitlin‚Äôs help to finally get 1A, never having heard it before. 
Once I had the completed grid I could see that none of the spans were obscure for me, other than 1A, but they were the very devil to fill. 
Laughed out loud at 38A. Was thinking surfers.

My only odd moment was 53A. I did a rare google search as I had absolutely nothing. The Grammy award for best record 1976 came up as Captain and Teneille‚Äôs  Love Will Keep Us Together. What the?

To cap this off I then discover this is a debut. Bravo Mr McMahon, bravo.
Absolute smasher! I was a little intimidated at first but when I immediately guessed 1A correctly I was ready for the rest. Great puzzle, great debut!

Brilliant debut.

Those spanner stacks 
flowed like a waterfall‚Ä¶

Thank you Scott, for this gem!

*Chef‚Äôs kiss*

Turned out this was not all that difficult, despite the intimidating grid!  I did go down a few garden paths (ABLE WAS I ERE I SAW... SPEAR before LANCE, UTILITY INFIELDERoops, BASEBALL ALL STARrats, RAT before CAD...Adult before ANIME, and SELAH before SALAH.

Whatever--it was good clean fun, and it took less than my cup of coffee, time-wise.  This is the second WHIT in the span of a few days...ditto WREN.

Putting the final borders on two quilts today!

Almost a personal best time and completed at 4:30am without caffeine! 
Licked my lips at first glance of the grid with all those triple spanners. I had a good idea of the palindrome and had enough crosses to not only confirm it but fill in the next two below it with a little deduction. 
The middle section gave me the first and last three downs which made the middle fall quite easily and I started the bottom with the first three downs which made the rest slip in beautifully. 
An elegant puzzle and fun to solve.

This is a superb Saturday puzzle... you learn a lot, which is the purpose of crossword puzzles... and it is logical and fun at the same time.  

It also does not rely on gimmicks, thank God.
What a fantastic puzzle!  One of my favorites solves in a long while.  Congrats on this debut
Fun, and fast! Finished in less than half my average Saturday time. Great construction on the long answers, if maybe a tad too easy? But I had a blast with it.

This grid breaks down into three barely-related mini-puzzles, which is a form that I generally don't like.

But when each "mini" contains a triple stack of spanners, all I can say is:

Lovely puzzle!
Brilliant debut, Scott McMahon!

And I agree with you @Caitlin, the inclusion of the obscure town of MAHON can't be mere coincidence.

With 3 triple-stacks, I was expecting it to be Natick Central, which is usually the case when constructors need to make long phrases mesh. Pleasantly surprised that it wasn't! Nice puzzle, as a result.

Pedant mode on: Hotel California was released in 1977 (presumably recorded in 1976).
Anyone else run through the entirety of ‚ÄúBob‚Äù by Weird Al while trying to solve 1 Across?
Loved this puzzle! Congrats on the debut!

Hmmmm. I suppose MAHON is obscure, unless you're a fan of the writings of Patrick O'Brian, or otherwise interest in the18th-century exploits of the Royal Navy. Port Mahon was an important British naval dockyard in the Med, before it was reluctantly ceded to Spain. An early gimme, for me.
I am absolutely in awe over this puzzle. The ability to stack even two fifteen letter fills is incredibly hard, but three sets of three! A spectacular achievement, Scott!
This puzzle is an extraordinary achievement and just the right mix of hard and fair.  Outstanding for any constructor, never mind a debut effort.  Well done!
Fun puzzle which I solved from the bottom up! Great debut and congratulations!!
I liked this puzzle overall, but in 2025, does the clue for 19A need to specify ‚Äúfemale‚Äù rapper? I can‚Äôt imagine ‚Äúmale‚Äù would be added for Kendrick or Jay Z.

I think this puzzle is pretentious. I respect the effort that went into it and the skill of connecting so many long words that it showcases but it is drenched in ego and feels like it was made more for the creator themself and an elite group of intellectuals than the average person who reads the times.

I loved the stacks! As the kids these days say, "If it it ain't got stacks, don't even aks!"

The kerfuffle du jour inspired me to find that "Love Will Keep Us Together" by Captain & Tennille was the 1976 Record of the Year(which I then saw Helen Wright mention). 

Did you know that-according to Wikipedia-early in her career Toni Tennille toured with the Beach Boys and "has since been known as the Beach Boys' one and only 'Beach Girl'"?

And how incredible is it that they've been awarding Grammys since 1959 and in all that time, objectively speaking, they've never made a mistake?!?! You rock, Grammys!!
Well done Scott! I came in between my Wednesday and Thursday averages.

Wow, this was great! 
I always start Saturday puzzles filled with trepidation, knowing that I will soon have to either give up entirely or resort to "autocorrect."

A good omen for me is the existence of 15-letter blank rows. One below another is awe-inspiring, but a three row stack borders on being mind-blowing. So, THREE TRIPLE STACKS? REALLY? (Sounds like the words on a pancake restaurant gift card.)

My journey today resembles Ms. Lovinger's: awed, deceived, misdirected-- but occasionally successful. And, I am proud to say, ultimately I completed it with no outside help or lookups.

Thanks for this puzzle. Best mental push-up I'm likely to find today. Can't wait for others from Mr. McMahon.

I second all the comments on the stacking achievement. I thought I wouldn‚Äôt have a SALAH (TIL it isn‚Äôt salam) but it came together. 

MUM, NEIN, JEANS clues among the many smiles.
2D was instant if you've read the Aubrey-Maturin series.   I re-read it this past year to avoid political news.  In that vein, the next few days make  ___ Pro Noblis appropriate.

I started this puzzle with some trepidation when I saw the three triple stacks,  only to find it later surprisingly easy & entertaining.  I don't know if it indeed is, or if it's that my few remaining brain cells decided to work together today, but I will congratulate Mr. McMahon for his debut.   I wonder what he is going to do to top the triple stacks. Thank You!

I whizzed through this puzzle in under 20 minutes, which was unexpected, given the triple stacks. It would have been even faster if I didn't have I MADE IT in the middle stack. Usually, I can judge Saturday's difficulty by 1A, and the palindrome was a gimme.
Very fun solve. Didn't much care for 1A but the corresponding downs were fair. Congrats!
Loved this puzzle. Very satisfying.
well, i'm not too coy to say this was fun.  i'm not sure if it was easy for a Saturday or if I'm just on the same wavelength as the constructor.  Enjoyed the creative clueing.

What a grid!

Sped through it like a breeze. I felt that I was very much on the same wavelength as the constructor.
For a brief moment I confused a palindrome with a limerick. It turns out THERE ONCE WAS A MAN has more than 15 letters.
53 across is incorrect
Loved the puzzle but not a fan, at all, of the grid. Felt like three separate puzzles (top, middle and bottom thirds) with very loose connections between them.

Did not know the palindrome, nor Minorca, and was flipping between nursery purchase being a "cot" or "pot". Seems when I read BRIT lit they call a baby's bed "cot", rather than "crib". ANYway...got it through logic. 
I was trying to think of a technical name for a food coma for 17A until I got a few letters. LOL 
Pretty much all the stacks fell for me that way - good cluing. Great for a debut!
OK here it is almost noon, and no cleaning has been done. I did walk 5 miles. Does that count?

Challenging! Got through it, but there‚Äôs an error that was missed during editing. It may have led many down the wrong path, although the answer becomes clear eventually. The hit won for best record in 1978, not 1976.

I had the initial palindrome as "A MAN A PLAN PANAMA" (which fits) and couldn't figure out what other palindrome started with A MAN A PLAN . . . totally forgot about A CANAL. Other than that, things weren't too tough. The top 3 rows were definitely more challenging than the bottom 3.

Despite my struggles at the top, I still was below my average solve time for a Saturday (although it should have been better, had my poor memory not betrayed me).
Unique grid‚Ä¶ one might almost call it a signature debut from Scott McMAHON.
